name: Dino D-Day
description: Frantic, multiplayer action involving Nazis and dinosaurs! What are you waiting for? This is World War II as it should have been!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP/Vista/7 Processor: 3.0 GHz P4, Dual Core 2.0 (or higher) or AMD64X2 (or higher)  Memory: 2 GB RAM  Hard Disk Space: 5 GB of free space Video Card: Video card must be 128 MB or more and with support for Pixel Shader 2.0b (ATI Radeon X800 or higher / NVIDIA GeForce 7600 or higher / Intel HD Graphics 2000 or higher). Sound: Direct X 9.0c compatible sound card

reviews.review_text: Nazi Dinosaurs with Cannons and Machine Guns on their backs. What more do I have to say?    Dino D-Day is a humorous WWII Multiplayer FPS about what would happen if not only did Adolf Hitler's science teams brought the dinosaurs back to life, but also gave them nerve controlled weapons, the intellegence to comprehend language, ideology, nationality, and not eat their masters? You get this silly game where Dinosaurs have cannons, machineguns, their own claws and abilities, and even suicide bombing mini dinos; I'm not kidding. The game got it's start as a single player mod for Half Life 2, but it was scrapped apparantly and it's assets turned towards a multiplayer game.   There are two teams, The Allies, and the Axis. With some memebers of either having special abilities to use.  The Allies are John Hardgrave (The Leader), who uses either the M1 Garand or the M1 Carbine. His ability is when he gets three kills, he can go into a Patriotic beserk spree! Punching facists with his super fists high into the air!   Then there's Joe Spencer, he uses either a Tommy Gun or a Grease Gun, his specialty is calling in artillary strikes onto a part of the map, which is useful for either clearing a certain chokepoint of enemies, or dealing damage to critical targets.   Up next is Nigel Blythe, English Gentleman with a Shotgun, and his choice of either a rocket launcher or a flame thrower to light those jerries up!   Supporting from the rear is Ilona Vike, cute as a button but sharp as a razorblade. This Soviet Rose is the sniper of the team and utilizes her rifle, her revolver for back up, and a dead rabbit to distract certain dinos into losing control and eating, leaving them vulnerable to either Ilona herself, or her comrades.   Supporting at the front is also Camille Brun the medic, she heals nearby teammates with her special or can chuck heal oozing medpacks for teammates to gather around.   Finally, there's Trigger, the wonder dino! Liberated from the Nazi Army, Trigger is the only Dino the allies have, and he's as deadly as he is cute, getting revenge on the long long hunt from carnivores millenia ago, Trigger uses his nerve controlled, swivel mounted 30. Browning Machine Gun on Facists, wether beast or man.   The Axis forces only have three humans, being mostly comprised of Facist dinosaurs!    Kurt Streicher is a simple soldier with no abilities to speak of, Armed with his rifle, his MP40, and some grenades, he does good on the front on his own.  Karl Hissman is the more interesting German, being a falconer, he's trained explosive, suicide Pterosaurs to fall onto where ever he points at, killing anyone nearby (Did I mention you can, if lucky, lock the Pterosaur onto an enemy?). Aside from that, he serves as the team's sniper against Ilona.  The final Human is Don Graff, the Medic and Vetrinarian for the Axis war machine. be wary that even though he is a simple medic, he is armed with an STG44.  The Facist Dinos include the classic Velociraptor, who can use his speed to surprise and overwhelm enemies, and even pounce onto them to rip their throats out.  The Dilophosaurus can pick up one of the many goats (did I mention there's goats in this game?) and lunge them at enemies for damage and laughs, as well as the ability to knock down enemies, pick them up, and toss them for a double kill!  The Desmatosuchus is a walking tank, armed with a medium but still powerful tank turrent, he can supress enemies and kill with splash damage. Be mindful that he and his spikes are big, so it's not easy to get through certain doorways.  The Stygimoloch is the Desmatosuchus, but more mobile, agile, less bulkly, and has a MG34 Machine gun instead of a cannon. He is the German Trigger.  The Microraptor can do it all! He can fly, claw people to death when they don't know it, and blind people with a deadly acid spit, while clawing them to death!  The Compsognathus, or Compy for short, is a suicide bomber dino, though small and his bomb is just a stick grenade, he is still fanatical, and with three kills from his claws, turns his grenade from a weak firecracker, to a powerful bomb that can kill many, and set others aflame!   Finally the grand daddy of them all, only avaliable on certain maps, The Tyrannosaurus Rex! You can't spawn as him, rather there's a 'waiting list' on the Axis team where a random player gets selected to become the Rex until either the end of the round, or death where upon another player is randomly chosen. He is nasty, Armed with two MG42s on the sides of his head, able to pick up and toss airplane bombs, he also uses his might roar to knock down enemies and if they're unlucky enough, The T-Rex can pick them up and eat them for health! His only problem is his pure size and slowness, making him a target for everyone.    The game comprises of three modes. Team Deathmatch (First team to 50 kills wins), King of the Hill (The side that controls the hill point for 3 minutes wins.), Control Points (First team to capture all points wins.), and Objective mode. Otherwise the game is your typical FPS combat, with the Allies being more for group tactics and shooting, while the Axis Dinos are more arena shooter.  Overall this is a fun cheap game, I got this for $1.99 when it was on sale the other day, and it's worth the money if you can find a crowded server. The game is active with a couple of players, so no worries about finding a big game. I would indeed reccomend this game.  Pros:  -Fun Gameplay -Gunplay is good -Dinoplay is amazing -Cheap  Cons:  -Weird Control choices (Holding the aim button while in toggle mode won't let you fire your gun, this can be switched to hold down though.)
Novel in concept, somewhat generic in practice // Recommended for fans of Team Fortress 2 who want to shake it up a bit*

Dino D-Day is an alternate universe shooter where the Nazi's have Dinosaurs. Dino D-Day is a multiplayer game where you can either fight against the overwhelming power of the Nazi army aided by Dinosaurs, or fight on behalf of the allied nations. You can play as human or dino in this interesting shooter. Visually its not a AAA Title, but it is still fun to play.

This is a pretty great FPS. There isn't much reason to not like it unless you don't like the FPS genre.  Pros: -All the weapons and classes are unlocked at the start (No in-game currency unlock ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t) -Classes seem balanced -Interesting classes (melee dinosaurs, dinosaurs with MG's) -Low price on sale (Only 99 cents and it goes on sale a lot) -Community is better compared to others -Doesn't take a lot to run the game -Entertaining -A couple of great jokes -Trading cards for those who want that stuff -T-Rex on some maps -You're able to change controls relatively easily  Cons: -Small playerbase (You'll usually see one or two servers active) -One or two maps where players are able to get to certain rooftops where they shouldn't be -There is one map where sometimes the capture won't work and it's just endless killing -Rare bug where you aren't able to switch weapons in the classes screen  Neutral: -First thing you want to do is turn off voice chat if you don't want a headache -It's an indie game -You'll see a couple of the same players around a lot -The Axis have more of a dinosaur selection while the Allies only have one -Yes, you can play as a human too  Do your friends a favor and get the 4-pack.

A game of truly rough n' tumble skirmishes set in the second world war. Nazis alone don't make for an edgy enough plot anymore, and zombies are a garish pink vibrating strap-on of an angle that's been utterly exhausted. Despite this, it still remains on the throne, an idea selling like hot cakes much like that decayed ol' king from warhammer 40K. So, What's next on the list? Dinosaurs? Sure, why not.   My first impressions are that the game plays rather nicely. Controlling dinosaurs and humans alike feels fairly fluid, though the 'runts' and humans are fixed in first person while the bigger dinosaurs take third. It would be nice to have the choice if there's variation to begin with. So You've got a mix of human and late cretatious characters to play as, and each team has a fairly unique roster to offer. Unfortunately, it's the Axis that are milking this historical re-jigging for it's worth, as they have around six or seven full dino variants to pick from. Allies only have the one, and the rest of your team is comprised of pink-♥♥♥♥♥ honkeys. This alone can sap the joy out of playing as an American, bar the fact the world hates you, but I wouldn't say it presents a significant disadvantage. I suppose there's just no satisfaction in beating on a dinosaur as a dinosaur, but rather playing Godzilla and crushing the fleeing people on a whim. This is presumably why teams are reversed each round.   My main gripe with this game as it stands are the maps. They seem lackluster in design and rather sparse. Vantage points are obvious and don't really appear to be very thought out, and you can't even sling a few shells through glass windows. Overall, the game seems a tad shallow and lacking potential for interesting, engaging tactics. It's a pretty standard formula (often likened to Team Fortress 2) with nothing terribly new to offer. Nevertheless, I can't say it isn't satisfying to flatten a few yanks using a goat flung from your gargantuan jaws, or with another yank that you'd previously managed to keel over. There's fun to be had in this game for sure, but it's a quick, silly fix of entertainment and not one of any real lasting value. Would I recommend the game? Sure, for a happy drunken hootenanny or something. It's worth a chuckle or two at the least.

Dino D-Day is a multiplayer team-based first-person action video game developed by 800 North and Digital Ranch and published by Valve Corporation. It was released as a digital download, via Steam, on April 8th 2011. The game is developed as a total conversion modification on the Valve Corporation's Source engine.  The premise of the game is that during World War II, Adolf Hitler found a way to resurrect dinosaurs for use in the war effort. Players can battle online choosing to serve either the Allied nations or the Nazis.The game has been described as a new twist on 'the overdone World War II FPS ... that has become a running joke in the industry and gaming press'.   Upon the game's initial release, both the Allies and the Axis had six different classes of soldier. The Allied classes range from assault troops, medics and heavy support. However, the Axis have three human and three dinosaur classes. The human classes comprise assault troops, snipers and medics; while the dinosaurs comprise an attack Velociraptor, Dilophosaurus, and a Desmatosuchus with a cannon mounted on its back. Additional classes were added to both teams at later dates bringing the total to seven classes for the Allies and nine for the Axis. The Allies gained a dinosaur class of their own, a Protoceratops with a mounted machine gun. The Axis gained a Stygimoloch with a mounted gun, a Compsognathus that acts as a kamikaze bomber with a grenade and a flying Microraptor. In certain maps, an Axis player can also be chosen at random to play as a Tyrannosaurus with a jaw-mounted machine gun. While powerful, the class counts as three kills in a team death match.

Dino D Day ... is okay ... it's funnish but its not tremendous.  Pros - * Kind of fun. Definitely unusual. * They just gave away a million copies on PCGamer, so its no longer dead. * It's sense of humour is great.  Cons - * Parts of the interface look like they are ripped straight from TF2 * [Scratch that, found a setting in graphics. By default it has a 'film grain' setting turned on, it makes a mess of graphics and I recommend getting rid of it.] Graphics don't look anything as good as in the promo-pics on the steam page.  * T-Rex aren't actually truly playable. There is just a rare random chance on some servers (not sure which) that someone may be picked to be one. * Pricey for what it is.  Conclusion? Get it extremely cheap or don't bother.

I have over 600 games in my Steam account, and the vast majority of them are still unplayed. So now I'm dedicating an hour to each of these games and writing a series of One Hour Reviews. An hour isn't very long to judge a game on, so think of this as more of a first impression, and take this review in the spirit in which it's given. Be sure to read other reviews from players who have spent more time in the game.   One Hour Reviews #47 - Dino D-Day  This is such a strange concept. I can't even imagine where the developers came up with this idea of mixing Axis vs. Allies with dinosaurs. What's even more strange is that this fusion somehow works.  Playing the humans is much like you'd expect from a class based shooter, which choices like playing a medic, a sniper, or an assault type class. The dinosaurs change things up by replacing weapons (for the most part, a few dinos still have mounted guns) with abilities like melee attacks or spitting poison.  One thing I noticed though the distribution isn't exactly even. The story (such as it is) has the Axis team responsible for bringing back the dinosaurs, so that side has virtually all of the dinos to choose from, while the Allies have only one dino (liberated from the other side).  The game offers a variety of game types, which I noticed would change based on the map I selected. The game comes with a decent number of maps to start with, and I also saw an option for loading custom maps. Every map seemed to have the option for deathmatch, and capture the flag was another common option. Deathmatch plays just like I expect it would. Capture the flag looked pretty simplistic, there were only 3 flags to capture on the level I played. I saw where a few maps had an objective based game type, but I didn't have time to check this out in my first hour of play. Same goes for a deathmatch variant with T-Rexes.  This is definitely one of those games that is really hard to evaluate on just an hour of play, but I had a lot of fun trying out everything.  It is possible to play singleplayer with bots if thats your thing. The bots have a difficulty level that you can select. But obviously the real intent of this game is to play multiplayer. There isn't any real matchmaking going on here, you just have a basic server select, and from there you can pick a side. There didn't seem to be a huge number of people playing, but I also had no trouble finding an active server to hop into.  Presentation wise the graphics are fine, but you aren't going to be blown away by anything. It does have the typical options you'd expect like changing resolution, playing in a window (bordered or borderless) or fullscreen, and various other options as well.  I can't give this game anywhere near a complete review with only an hour in, but I had a lot of fun in my first hour. And for only $9.99, it looks like a good value for the variety of maps and game types you get. I don't know that this would be a game to keep my attention for a long time, but it definitely makes for a nice alternative to the AAA shooters that are out there.
The only flaw is the lack of players (always a couple servers full though).  BUY it, PLAY it!  Good Goyim

Dino D Day is a fantastic and honestly underrated game. The game started out as a Source mod that eventually got to star in its own show! The game is in an alternate universe where the Third Reich somehow brought back dinosaurs through science! The game pits German soldiers and dinosaurs vs allied soldiers and a single dinosaur.   The gameplay is smooth, which is from what you would expect from a source engine game. It's easy to learn, somewhat easy to master, and an absolute blast to play.   The game has a few hundred people playing it, so finding a populated server isn't difficult to find. It's only a pity that more people don't play it. When it goes on sale, do you and your friends a favor and buy like 10 copies at 99 cents a piece. The game is silly, fun and the playerbase is friendly!

I was able to get the game for free and I still feel ripped off.  I knew the game had a brutal Metacritic score but I thought, you know, Nazi dinosaurs -- how can the game be that awful? I started it up and saw it was multiplayer only and I realized I was in for a bad time. I tried to start a game, but the menus are only partially navigable with a controller, which sucks in Big Picture mode. I joined a game and chose a Nazi velociraptor. The game started and, to balance the teams, it made me some Allied woman with a clunky sniper rifle. I wasn't pleased, but I moved around the dimly lit Italian piazza level with the sniper, unable to shoot most anything but acquainting myself with the controls all the same. I accomplished nothing by the time my team lost, but I was ready for my first full game.  The next game booted up in the same poorly lit level, and I saw my velociraptor's claws before me. Three seconds later, the game informed me I had been sent to the Allies to play as the sniper again. Comfortable with the controls, I mostly impotently shot into the inky blackness. I got at least one kill but I don't know when that happened. All I really remember was getting obliterated by the gun-equipped T-Rex and getting killed every time I stepped out of the Allies' hole. I manned the turret, but either there was no action in front of me, or I was instantly picked off by a sniper. The Allies lost again.  The third game started and this time, by some miracle, I was allowed to be the velociraptor. A newly assigned teammate announced to the world how excited he was to play as the T-Rex. I prowled around the same pitch-black level, killing goats and searching aimlessly for battle. The velociraptor moved quickly and the melee attack felt fun to use. This brief stretch was by far the most fun I had with Dino D-Day. When I finally found the Allies' area, I was shot at from afar or occasionally an enemy would be shooting off a flamethrower while spinning in a circle. Twice I was able to engage such a player in close contact. One time I swear I slashed at him three times. THREE TIMES. His health was nearly gone, but his flamethrower did me in. That was the closest I came to actual, palpable combat. Most of the time I simply saw no one, and would run in a pack with other Axis dinosaurs or soldiers, or occasionally run around with the T-Rex -- not so much for protection, but simply to try to be in the right place at the right time to engage the enemy. I found the Allied base and saw all entry points with a big red-circle-with-a-slash sign in front of the doorway. I was unable to enter. The Allies could spend all day in there firing at the dinosaurs, and that's what they did.  My team lost for the third time. I turned the game off and uninstalled it. Do not buy this game. Do not play this game. War truly is hell, even with dinosaurs.

Shoot dinos Shoot goats Shoot nazis / allies  Pros: Fun Steam cards Cheap (Under $1 on sale on in bundle) Multiplayer OK controls  Cons: 7 people in the world left playing this game Game actually sucks - I mean REALLY SUCKS.  Overview: It's under $1 with steam cards. Yes it sucks, but you should be able to get at least $1 worth of fun out of it.

TL;DR  If I had payed more than $5, this review would be negative.  Get it when it's on sale for less than $5.   Same-old, same-old repetitive FPS + dinosaurs.      What can I say, lol.  Such a fresh take on FPS I simply had to try it.   I would have never payed the full asking price ($10), that is simply rediculous for a game like this. I got it on-sale for the price of a crappy phone app ($1) and I was well pleased with my investment. I'd reccomend you wait for it to go on sale, or you will be harshly dissapointed. It has no campaign, no unique game modes, and it has basic graphics and effects.     That being said, online connectivity is better and faster than AAA titles like CoD and BF. I've yet to experience ANY connection related LAG. The classes are well balanced*, and each class actually heavily affects playstyle required to succeed. I also have not encountered any hackers yet, so I'm guessing i'm either just lucky or the anti-cheat actually works. The rag-doll physics have been exagerated, it's a nice touch for the theme and creates some funny moments.  I don't think my $1 could have provided me with any better, aside from helping a starving child in Africa or something.   (*= execpt for the hardgrave class. Hardgrave is the only class with a 'kill streak ability'. After you get 3 consecutive kills as hardgrave, you can press E to active glowing fists that can one hit almost all enemies. Either the hardgrave ability needs to be removed, or kill streak abilities need to be added to all classes.)

I got this game for free on the PCGamer-BundleStars givaway a while back, and ultimately, the game ended up sitting in my library without much use so far. The elevator pitch for Dino D-Day would go somewhere along the lines of 'It's a third person shooter set in world war II, but with a twist: You can play as a T-Rex with a machine gun'.  The idea sounds fun, original and interesting, but the gameplay is flat and generic, without any noticeable difference between the classes, and the visual style grey and unappealing, which manages to lay waste to an ultimately interesting arena-style level design.  When I got the main idea of the game, I wanted to like it, I really did. But the game is ultimately unappealing both visually and gameplay-wise, and I cannot recommend anyone spending their money on it.

Well Hello there Pilgrim,  Looking for adventure? Exploration of a foreign land? Have a hatred for all things scaly? Yearn to serve your country?  Than the Allied Forces have a job for you!  Boy, have the Nazi's done it this time, thought they were bad before? Well the Scary Schnitzel lovin Monsters out did themselves. They've brought back Scary Man Eating Dinosaurs! Long dead creatures with an insatiable blood lust and hatred of Freedom and Liberty only Hitler himselve could muster.  Don't you fret! We haven't lost this fight just yet!  Recruitment for the Extinctioneers is in high swing! Looking to knock some Nazi Dinosaurs right in the gullet? Well Capt. Jack Hardgrave has all the experience in large lizard beating action you'll need to learn from!  Don't let Ol' Hitler beat Uncle Sam! Join now! ````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````````` I'm not joking when I say this game is JUST LIKE THAT.  Team vs Team, Nazis vs Allies, Man vs Beast.  This game has everything you're looking for in a game, especially if you're looking for a game worth playing! Addictive multiplayer fun, with nothing but non-stop Nazi Dinosaur beating goodness. Want to be the dinosaur? Well guess what bub, this game switches teams every round. Think Freedom is for the goody goodies? That's fine, cause the dinosaurs are pretty much elite killing machines bent on total world domination.  Not only are there team v team maps, but specialty maps where Ol' Hitler unleashes one of his T-Rex's on the poor Allies!  What more could you want in a game?

If you like laughing hilariously or playing a game that is not serious what-so-ever or both at the same time, then Dino D-Day is your choice.  Two teams are thrown at eachother (one Allies the other Axis, obviously) in your normal FPS PVP gamemodes. However, there is a small twist. There's mother♥♥♥♥ing DINOS running around. Allies have access to only one dino and 6 human classes while the Axis have access to three human classes and four or five dinos. Other than that, it's fairly simple gameplay. Snipers snipe, medics heal, riflemen shoot things, demo blows ♥♥♥♥ up, and dinos eat people! However it gets dull. Fast. The game itself is more or less something that I personally would boot up for a few laughs with friends, or would play for an hour and then go do something else.  There is a co-op survival mode, although it just has you running around the map doing various objectives for money that can get you new weapons and tools. In my less than extraordinary or professional opinion, I give it two stars.   Okay eating people is hilarious, 4.5 stars out of five.
